Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Story: I was finishing up the last touches on my client’s hair when I saw her frown at her reflection. She was a first-time visitor, and I could sense her disappointment with the colour tone. My heart raced—I knew how important it was to make a good impression, to listen carefully, and to fix any concerns right away. Just as I was about to ask her what she’d like changed, my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a message from my sister: “Can you call me? I really need you right now.” She never asked for help unless it was serious. I felt a wave of guilt and worry. As her sister, I was supposed to be there, to support her no matter what. But as a hairdresser, I couldn’t just leave my client, especially when she needed reassurance and a solution. My mind spun with the weight of both expectations, torn between the urge to rush to my sister’s side and the responsibility to my client sitting anxiously in my chair.
